profileText: A Representative from Massachusetts; born in Exeter, N.H., March 3, 1783; attended the common schools and Williams College, Williamstown, Mass., for two years; was graduated from the College of William and Mary, Williamsburg, Va., in 1803; studied law; was admitted to the bar and practiced in Salem, Mass., and Portland, Mass. (now Maine); collector of customs in Boston 1812-1829; served as brigadier general commanding the Volunteers in the defenses of Boston Harbor in the War of 1812; member of the State constitutional convention in 1820; member of the State house of representatives in 1829; served in the State senate in 1830; elected as an Anti-Jacksonian to the Twenty-second Congress (March 4, 1831-March 3, 1833); was an unsuccessful candidate for reelection in 1832 to the Twenty-third Congress; served as adjutant general of Massachusetts 1834-1843; mayor of Roxbury 1847-1851; president of the Massachusetts Horticultural Society; author of many books; died in Portland, Maine, on July 29, 1851; interment in Forest Hills Cemetery, Roxbury, Mass.

note.content: Elected to represent the Norfolk district.

researchRecord.name: In the T.M. Acosta Papers, ca. 1820-1822, 1 folder.
researchRecord.description: A series of letters written in 1820 by T.M. Acosta addressed to Gen. Henry A.S. Dearborn. Acosta was an con-artist who described himself as a recent immigrant and detailed various needs for money. A note written by Dearborn on the back of an 1822 letter explains that Acosta also used the pseudonym Manero and received money from other Boston patrons.

researchRecord.name: 1834, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Josiah L. James to H.A.S. Dearborn written on August 25, 1834. In the letter, Josiah James discusses arrangements being made by 40 to 50 families to emigrate to Illinois; invites Dearborn to aid and influence that undertaking. Includes details of agreement signed by all parties regarding the prospective settlement's location, finances, land division, etc.

researchRecord.name: 1850, 2 items.
researchRecord.description: Two letter from Henry Alexander Scammel Dearborn to Mrs. Potter written on October 9, 1850. In the letter, Henry Dearborn asks Mrs. Potter to obtain an impression of Mary Queen of Scot's seal ring from Mrs. Moses Ives. Another letter from Henry Dearborn to Mrs. Moses B. Ives written on October 18, 1850. In the letter, Henry Dearborn thanks Mrs. Ives for the impression of Mary Queen of Scot's seal ring and accompanying note.

researchRecord.name: 1831, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Alexander Hill Everett to General H.A.S. Dearborn written on May 17, 1831. In the letter, Alexander Everett asks if Dearborn would like to be included in a group formed by Everett and his brother, to hold "from time to time a meeting of a few confidential friends for the purpose of exchanging ideas upon the current political affairs."

In the letter, John Mason inquires about rumors that Boston builders plan to construct houses in Washington at a cheaper rate than the Washington builders; offers help to them, as he approves this project; mentions his parents' continuing good health.
